For the question at the end, the intended answer is not "the handle lets you go in three dimensions", because for that matter a sphere is three-dimensional, but you could never solve it there. Think about what makes the surface of the mug (or a doughnut) distinct from that of a sphere, and how that affects the argument. I think I went years knowing that Euler's formula looks different on different surfaces but had never really thought through why. In particular, the exercise will set good intuitions for learning about homology, if that's something in your future.

Also, my apologies for two names typos here: Veritasium, and James Grime (evidently I accidentally pluralized him to "Grimes"). That's what I get for throwing on titles late at night, my bad!

Maybe I accidentally obfuscated this too much in the editing, but all the math guys most certainly were familiar with the puzzle. I mean, three of them make and sell the thing! Although I’m unsure of this statement, I’m pretty confident about the following…

The mug is basically just a weird sphere with a handle, which allows four couples (x,y,z) to exist on the same x and y (but not z) coordinates.
For example, on a given sphere, only two points (0,0,z) can exist : (0,0,0) and (0,0,4). This is because all points (0,0,z) for which z does not equal 0 or 4 are either outside or inside the sphere (z=0 is on the sphere’s back and z=4 in on its front).
However, on the sphere with a handle (the mug), four points (0,0,z) are possible (at specific angles): (0,0,0), (0,0,4), (0,0,6) and (0,0,7). This is because all points (0,0,z) for which z does not equal 0, 4, 6 or 7 are located outside or inside the sphere/handle (z=0 being on the sphere’s back and z=4 on its front, and z=6 being on the sphere-facing side of the handle while z=7 is on the you-facing side of the handle).

In a nutshell, a straight line passing by the middle of a sphere can only cross it twice, while one passing by the middle of a ring (aka sphere with a handle) can cross it up to four places at once.

Here I decomposed the mug to a sphere-with-a-handle-thing in order to (I hope) make it more easily understandable, even though a mug is basically just a weird shaped ring.

The problem is that the proof assumes that all loops divide space into multiple regions, but not all loops on a torus divide it. A loop around the hole doesn't, and neither does a loop through the hole.

So the breakdown is actually that on a torus, you can get from one region to another without crossing a line. As was discussed below, a piece of paper where left wraps to right and top wraps to bottom is equivalent to a torus. So let's take your animation in the state with seven edges, and draw a line from the blue vertex into the black region, going around the right house and then off to the right, wrapping around to the left, and connecting to the left house. What have you done in the context of the puzzle? In theory, you have divided the black region into two. But since top wraps to bottom, you can draw a line from the red vertex into the black region hitting the top of the graph, wrapping around to the bottom and connecting to the right house. You have managed to cross from the upper large region to the lower one without crossing a line.

Or put another way, it is false to say that on a torus, every edge either connects to a new vertex or creates a new region, since it was possible to draw an edge that does neither.

Looking back at this video, I decided to take another crack at the problem. I originally thought "well, it's because of the genus, duh" and left it at that. The genus counts the number of holes in a space, informally. But what I realized looking back at it is that the argument presented in the video for the Euler characteristic relies on the fact that returning to a vertex MUST close a region. We can think of our surface as made of construction paper and the edges as cuts. Returning to the same vertex then corresponds to closing a loop, and closing a region corresponds to that loop making a removable piece of paper--it disconnects the space. On a genus 0 surface, this happens with any loop--any closed cut in our construction paper splits it into 2 pieces. But on a torus, and therefore on a mug, exactly one full loop can be made before the next cut disconnects it. Thus returning to a vertex (closing a loop) on a torus (or mug) does not necessarily correspond to closing a region (disconnecting the surface), so the argument fails. This is directly connected (no pun intended) to the formal definition of genus: the maximal number of closed loops that can be removed in a space without rendering it disconnected. However, I can't see how it directly relates to the Euler characteristic of the torus being zero (without resorting to 2 - 2g) from this argument. I wonder if someone else could pitch in?

The thing that makes the mug special is that it allows certain portions to be on a different plane of 3d than the others. Not just it being 3d, because while a sphere is 3d, it runs into the issue that the surface still acts flat. A mug has the handle, which essentially creates a whole new plane on the 3d surface removed from the rest, meaning it bends the normal rules a bit.

Edit: aka it means you can actually use the 3d nature by taking advantage of depth.

So to my proof the puzzle [IN 2D SPACE] is impossible. The epiphany was, if the lines may Not cross the orientation of the houses & utilizes is unimportant. So now I'm going to have describe something that is better show graphically. So here goes.
Draw the houses in a line as before. Now, & here's the revelation. Draw one utilise above the middles hours, draw another utility below the middle house. We'll do the third utility in a moment. Now it is trivial to join the two drawn utilities to the three houses. Which gives a diamond shape with a line down the middle. Now let's put the third utility on the paper. There is no place, in or outside the diamond, where this last utility can be placed. That can be joined to more than two houses.
QED.

I used to play a lot of flash games when I was a child, and one of them was this exact puzzle (on a flat surface). I tried for hours at the time to find a way to solve it, before realising it was impossible. The game was coded so that every time 2 lines cross each other, every single line you've drawn would disappear, but if you somehow managed to beat the thing, a victory screen would pop up. As a matter of fact, it was possible to beat it by exploiting tools at hand to trick the memory of the game into thinking you didn't release the click, and linked the last source to the last house, even tho it went straight through one of the other lines. The idea was to draw every line but the last one, making sure those never crossed, and then for the last one, hold the click, draw till you're realy close to the line you need to go through, and while holding the left click, press the right click so the window with options would pop up. Once it popped up, release the left click, and simply move your cursor to the last house, and click it. This method was the easiest, but didn't work consistently, so another method would have you clicking on the "zoom in" option in the right click pannel instead of going straight for the house. It tricked the computer more consistently, but this time the issue was that the zoom would sometimes move your cursor right into the line you were trying to go through (or sometimes another one), overlapping both lines, and resetting the game. It was pretty fun for me as a child to realise it was impossible, even tho I didnt understand the reason at the time, and it's realy cool to revisit this problem through this video. Thanks to you, I can now understand why it was impossible.

The solution to this problem looks really clean using a 2D representation of a torus, e.g. the system in games like PacMan where the upper wall teleports to the bottom, and the left wall teleports to the right, and vice versa. From there it's the same drawing you did before adding the last two lines, where one line goes through the LR teleportation wall to reach one house, and the other line goes through the UD teleportation wall to reach the other house without crossing. Note: this doesn't work on a 2D representation of a sphere because the lines cross "off-screen".

The proof that 5 regions where each region requires 4 edges requires 10 distinct edges felt kind of hand wavey. You assume you can only count an edge at most twice, but why can't you count it three times? It's easy to come up with such an example.

I proved it by using the case for K_{3,2}, which is possible. For K_3,2 where you have 3 utilities and 2 homes, there are 3 sets of 4 points, where there are 2 points from each partition, each defining an enclosed region.

By Euler's characteristic there are 3 faces (including the unbounded, infinite space). That means of the 3 sets of 4 points, one of the sets, actually encloses the other two! WLOG, call the enclosed regions 1, 2, 3, where 3 is the union of 1 and 2. Now let's add the sixth point. WLOG say the sixth point is not a utility but a home.

There are two cases.
1) The sixth point is inside 3, which means it's in 1 or 2. WLOG, say it's in 1. Well there's a utility that is outside of 1, so to connect the sixth point to the last utility, it must cross the boundary of 1.

2) The sixth point is outside of 3. Well there is a utility inside of region 3. So the sixth point/third home must cross into region 3, crossing its boundary.

Now I solved it on a sheet of paper with opposite ends identified, which is a torus, so that is basically the mug. In my solution I only have 3 regions and it actually looks like each region has every node at its border. So I think that is part of the solution. Also note that this checks out with the euler characteristic of the torus being 0, so with 6 nodes and 9 edges, we indeed expect 3 faces.

Like in the showcase following 7:40, when we connect the bottom middle node to the top left node, if this was on the torus, we could go around one of the cycles of it. We then split the drawing area into two regions again, but actually due to the other ends of the torus being connected, they are one and the same surface! We can actually do the same trick once more going around the other cycle of the torus, again splitting the drawing area in half, while not really splitting that region into two. So basically for each cycle of the torus we get an "out of jail" card to draw an edge to a lit up node without enclosing a region. You can actually see this even easier, if you just consider one nodes on the torus, then you can connect it along the cycles and you just end up with one face overall. The euler characteristic then gives 1-2+1=0 as expected.

Another way you can make sense of it is also that those edges you draw are then not bordering two surfaces, but just one, so that also messes up with the way of counting we have employed earlier.

What is somehow really important here, is that if you draw a node corresponding to one cycle, it's the other cycle that allows this trick. So on a cylinder for example it doesn't work because you have only one cycle. The only edge you could draw there that would not resulting in a new face would be the one connecting both boundaries of the cylinder, so that doesn't really help us.

The handle has nothing to do with the solution. The fact that you are working on a cylindrical object is the only condition needed to make the puzzle solvable. Going under or through the mug is also unnecessary.

@17:08 when you asked the question: the puzzle is solvable only if you can go 'through' the plane. While a sphere has similar properties to a toroid in that it is a single plane with no boundary it doesn't provide a "through" component. The addition of the hole morphs a two dimensional space in three dimensions but eliminates the boundary (edge) of the two dimensional plane while providing a path through. On a sphere with regard to lines X and Y are functionally the same thing. On a toroid, however, only one or the other can effectively transit through the hole. Stated another way one can circumnavigate the widest cross-section, the other can transit the narrowest.

Okay okay okay, I think I found a solution (almost four years late, but whatever)

So, Euler's formula should always equal two on a solid object. I checked this with a cube, and sure enough: 8 vertices-12 edges+6 faces=2.

I used Blender, a 3D software, to generate a few toruses, and plugged the numbers into the formula, and found that the answer was always 0, not 2. After giving it a think, I realized that
Euler's Formula does not apply to toruses because it has no ends. The torus is missing the two end faces, and therefor the solution to Euler's Formula is two less than we expect.

If you were to take a bite out of the donut, the torus would have two end faces, and so Euler's Formula would apply.

To anyone who thinks this is impossible, there are actually two solutions. One is impractical and one is practical. If you do this on paper, poke a hole in the paper and then the wires meet all houses “without crossing. However, it is impractical because the wires don’t actually make it to the house. The practical solution is wiring gas, water, and heating to house 1. Then wire house 1 to house 2, and house 2 to 3. All wires make it to all the houses without crossing

This is absolutely solvable if you are an electrician working in America using the National Electrical Code. As an instructor in electrical, NEC 230.6 allows one electrical service of one premise to pass through another premise, as long as it is in a conduit that originates outside the premise and finishes outside the premise, plus is encased in 2 inches of brick or concrete. It may also pass through the foundation of one building to get to the other as long as it is ran in a conduit which is encased in 2in or covered by 2in or more of concrete. The third and final solution to this, according to the National Electrical Code, is to install it in a Raceway or conduit 18in below the Earth passing Below one building. Conclusion: So as long as you draw the electrical line through one of the houses, this is absolutely doable and more importantly, LEGAL. The instructions never said you couldn't.

As to why Euler’s formula breaks down on a mug (or a torus), I THINK it’s because you cant divide a torus into 2 regions with 1 line IF that line wraps around the hole or goes through it. Additionally you can’t divide the torus into 2 regions with 2 lines IF 1 of those lines wraps around the hole and the other goes through it. So essentially we can create 2 additional lines  that are GUARANTEED NOT to create a new region or face, even if they are connected to 4 “lit” vertices which throws off Euler’s formula. After drawing this puzzle on a piece of paper, it became clear that doing this puzzle on a torus is EXACTLY the same as doing it’s on a 2D plane that acted like a Pac-Man level where leaving on one side let’s you emerge from the opposite side. And it makes so much sense because if you roll up a paper and make the long edges touch and then again to where the short edges touch, you’d have a torus with 2 bisecting lines yet only 1 region.

How? Easy.

The contestants were assuming a rule NOT stated. They assumed the house was some sort of barrier but that is not stated in the rules.

Solution:

0. First draw it out on paper. 3 house areas and 3 utility areas.

1. Connect the center utility to each house with a straight line.

2. On the left most utility draw a straight line up to just barely touch the left house.

3. Draw a line just outside the line in step to to the middle 3 third of the left house then straight across the first house to terminate in the 2nd house.

4. Draw a line just outside the line in step 4 into the center 1/3 if the left house and draw a straight line through to terminate in the house on the right.

5. We do the mirror of steps 2,3,&4 but mirrored starting from the right most untility in the upper 1/3rd of the houses extending from left toright this time.

Congrats. You have 9 lines that NEVER cross each other and each house has at least 1 connecring line to each utility.

Here's a much much simpler and intuitively visual proof to why this puzzle impossible:
Consider the ability to move any of these points around and add them on one by one, so you can get clean clear lines which do not bend all over the place. You will inevitably reach something which looks like this:
u
/|\
hhh
\|/
u
Where h is house and u is utility. The third utility is not on this plot yet. Notice how there are three "regions"; two inside one outside.
For this puzzle to be possible, there must be a region (to place the third utility) where all the houses are "accessible" ie all the houses vertices of one region. Notice how there is no region which satisfies that. Proof complete.

I was going to go with the "handle allows u to go into 3 dimensions". But as the pinned comment pointed out, a sphere is 3D too so and didnt support a solution and hence i thought more and actually found a reasonable explanation.

If u set the x and y coordinate of a point on a sphere, the z coordinate is fixed by default given that we dont allow lines to go through the sphere's body. So essentially a spheres surface is not really 3 dimensional if that makes any sense.
While the mug handle tho, allows for u to have 2 possible z coordinates for one particular set of x and y coordinates allowing the lines to pass through the same x,y point without really intersecting.

This problem can’t be solved because of the terms required by the problem to solve it, not because it can’t be solved if we allow for different rules.

For example, if we allow daisy-chaining, we can solve this without 9 lines. If we allow non-planar overlap, aka 3D, each house could be connected with no planar overlap. In fact, this is how utilities work right now—we have buried power, water, sewage, gas, cable, and more underneath us (subways too!) yet these don’t run into each other.

While the artificial arithmetical problem can’t be solved in its own terms, it doesn’t necessarily matter. In fact, the ability to think outside of constrained limits is ultimately more useful in terms of application.

As a final illustration, modern computer processors and networks allow for layered ring topologies or even shared topologies where each node is designed with many-to-many interconnection points such and operations between discrete units can occur without interfering with others. For a very long time we have done this with 2D lithographies—as long as we allow for internodal connections (aka daisy chains).

I truly dislike these artificial problems because they simply aren’t representative of real constraints to actual problems. While mathematics people may find them to be interesting, they simply aren’t useful for aiding the solution of real world problems.

Hello! I’m thinking about the last question - I know very little about the mathematical properties of donuts (or 3D shapes in general), but here are some observations I made that feel like they could be pointing to an answer? Lmk if I’m wrong…

A donut kind of has two “planes” (except not really because a donut is a bunch of circles) - the circumference where you trace around the donut, and the one where you trace through the donut hole. Eight of the lines can be drawn on one “plane” without crossing, but the second “plane” is required to draw the ninth line.

Again, I’m not a mathematician, so I don’t really have the concepts/language to back this up, but I will be looking out for a proper explanation of this!

For me it took 2 sheets of paper to figure it out. I stopped watching around the second chapter of the video to try it out myself cause I was curious. My solution was simple: make the mug a sphere. Instead of making the lines of each house( triangle) connect to the utility ( circle) nearest to them on the middle and take the long way around it would have the way to the answer. Then have the 2 outer triangles have lines that goes up within the outer lines so that they are now in-between the middle and outer triangles you can now connect them to the middle circle. Now that leaves the middle triangle unconnected to the outer circles, hense making use of the inside space. (Yes it is possible to make the middle triangle connect to the opposing circle immediately but it will make it harder visually on what we are trying to see.) Now because the 2 opposite sides of the triangle (houses) hasn't connected with the exact opposite side of the circles (utility) they would cross out (on paper do a diagonal line towards the corners of the paper) to the exact opposite side.
I realized after folding the paper into a cylinder multiple times that no matter what these last 2 lines will cross. Then I saw the handle of the mug and the rest is I the video.

Just started watching. I want to point out an exception to this impossibility not resulting from math, but from the defining language:
"At no point may two lines intersect."
Well, just draw the lines through the houses and you get 3 curves that end up as parallel lines and never intersect.
While this is, to a degree, mere sophistry.. It still has relevance in demonstrating the importance of clearly outlining the ruleset and conditions for solving a problem.
In education, these kinds of exceptions only show up on IQ tests. In the workforce, they'll show up constantly whether or not you notice them. It's good to practice thinking outside of the box: Even for a mathematician. Because sometimes, the rules allow for unintended solutions.

i think it goes a little beyond the whole 3d thing. but it helps to explaiin why it worked on a mug and not a sphere. a mug is technically an irregular shape, as the handle allows kind of a cheat code to eulers formula. think about it like this...  on a sphere or even a 2d space, no matter where you draw the lines, they will intersect. the mug is kinda like a 2d plane on a 3d surface. ill explain. you cant just draw a line through the center of the mug through the cup space for a drink because then you would have to draw on thin  air. so, in effect, you can only draw in one of 4 directions on the mug. up, down, left or right. this is why i say its a 2d plane on a 3d surface.  there is no Z axis.... unless you use the cup handle. does this make sense? this is why the cup handle breaks the puzzle because it introduces a z axis. hopefully this explains it!

The puzzle is NOT impossible on flat sheet of paper.
The houses are not points. The classic solution to the puzzle is therefore that a line goes 'under' or 'through' a house.
Thinking of the houses as points is an error of trying to reduce the problem to a mathematical principle which it is not.

Peterson proved we cant have a 3-regular bipartite plane graph.  The main reason is that we obtain an odd cycle using 3-regular plane graphs. Firstly we can't have 3-regular on odd vertices as the sum of degrees would be odd, impossible.  Secondly, we see for all the 3-regular graphs on an even number n of vertices, it would require a base case.  This is unachievable on a 3-regular bipartite plane graph, due to the existence of an odd cycle; that is what is to be proven.

SPOILER:












When you add another edge, it is possible to not add a vertex OR a region. It is possible to add E without changing V or F, hence Euler’s formula does not hold.

And to do that you need to specifically draw over the handle. Once you do you will notice while it LOOKS like you cut the cup in half, you didn’t. The region is still connected UNDER the handle. That’s why you can draw another edge underneath. The rules to this puzzle in order to make it impossible is incomplete. Not crossing any lines is not enough. I used to do this in grade school and solved it on paper with that rule only. Since all lines start and end on edges of the utility/house and the utility and houses have dimensional space, and there is no rule given that you can't pass a line through a house/utility to get to another house, as long as you don't cross the lines, then it is fair game and you can do it, and that is how you solve this puzzle. At least until they add the rule that you also can't pass a line through a utility or a house, then yes this is impossible at least on the paper version. On a torus you can actually draw a line between vertices that neither reach a new vertice nor create a new region. For example 4 vertices on a ring around the hole of the donut connected by 4 edges. On a sphere there would be a north and a south region and you'd have to cross the line to get from one to the other. But on a torus you can just go through the hole in the middle which makes it one region so the last edge hasn't introduced a new vertice or region, it kind of removed the hole.

Imagine a plane as wrapping paper. To prove something is topologically equivalent to a plane, you must be able to wrap the paper around its entire surface without cutting or piercing through the paper or mug. It seems like this is no problem, but you can’t actually wrap the paper around both the outside and inside of the handle unless the paper folds itself together. Basically, this represents taking two non-adjacent points on a plane and folding the plane such that the two points are smushed against each other. This means you are teleporting from one point to another in a different “dimension” and not actually traveling in the plane. This allows an edge in the Euler formula to not actually be on the plane, but rather teleport between two points on a plane by taking the secret teleportation passageway.

My bit of thought as the homework: as provided in the hint by 3Blue1Brown, the mug is topologically equivalent to a doughnut, or torus. Imagine starting with a piece of paper (a 2D-plane); in order to warp it into a torus, you'd make a cylinder by making the long edges touch AND you'd then make the short edges touch each other. In comparsion, a shape without a hole in it, such as a cylinder, would have only one of the edges wrap onto itself. So, the torus being equivalent to a piece of paper where you can wrap around both the short AND the long edges, makes this puzzle solvable on it, and hence on the mug.

The way this breaks the proof in the puzzle, is that it allows for an edge that connects two vertices, without forming a region boundary.

I think the proof breaks down in that the regions no longer all have only 4 edges. If you think about it as the handle's line being in a 3rd dimension, then each region that shares it's 2 nodes use that 3rd dimension. Those 3D regions then have 5 edges each instead of only 4.
We start with the calculation of "4 edges per region with each region sharing an edge with another region" = 4 * 5 / 2 = 10 edges necessary. We need 1 more edge. Then we add the "2 of those regions have a 5th edge which is shared between them", which accounts for that 10th edge.

My approach:
Start with utilities A, B, C, and 2 houses.
draw a linear arrangement: A -- house1 -- B -- house2 -- C
Connect: house1 -- C, A -- house2.

A really cool thing to this topic is there is a connection between Differentialgeometrie, Topology and  Complex analysis, that is the Gauß Bonnet Hopf theorem. It states, that for a given closed orientated two dimensional manifold, the total Gaussian curvature is equal to 2 pi times the Euler characteristic of that manifold(which is this beautiful formula V-E+F=chi) is equal to 2 pi times the total index of a vector field on this manifold. And since the total Gaussian curvature of a torus is equal to 0, the Euler characteristic has to be 0, thus the puzzle is possible. This formula can also be used to proof the hairy ball theorem. It is magnificent how all of these different fields play together!

Bonus: It is a theorem of [Ringel 1965] that the complete bipartite graph K(m,n) with m,n ≥ 2 embeds in a closed connected surface* S if and only if
χ(S) ≤ m + n - mn/2.
*without boundary, possibly non-orientable.

This means K(m,n) embeds in the torus if and only if mn ≤ 2(m + n) with the video witnessing the case m=n=3. Thus the problem is still solvable with 4 homes and 4 appliances, but not more.

Because of the hole, you actually have two chances to draw an edge without touching any new vertexes or making any new faces. Drawing one edge around the outside of the hole won’t make a new face because what would be two regions of space are connected through the inside of the hole. This only works once because any new edges drawn along the outside of the hole are either blocked from the hole by another edge or end up blocking other edges from the hole.

Drawing one edge the through the hole and around to the other end won’t make a new face because what would be two regions of space are connected by the outside of the hole. This also only works once reasons similar to the ones I’ve explained.

This can bring the total number of faces down to 3. The minimum number of edges required to make 3 faces is 6.

Making use of the hole would increase the number of edges per face, which isn’t what we want if we want to find the minimum number of edges, so figuring out the minimum number of edges on a donut should be exactly the same as figuring out the minimum number of edges on a piece of paper.

If you start with the minimum number of edges required for two faces, you need 4 edges, which makes a square. Remember that the space around the square counts as a face. To make a new face, you need to add at least one vertex. You can connect that vertex to two opposite corners of the square, which makes the new graph have 3 faces with 6 edges.

The minimum number of edges required is 6, which does not exceed the number of edges we have, so the task has not been proven impossible.

My homework answer:




It breaks down on a torus because it's possible on a torus to add an edge without adding a new (lit) vertex, and without creating a new region.

If you put a donut flat on a table, and place a vertex anywhere on the top of the donut, you can draw an edge doing down the outside of the donut, and back up the inside, connecting to the starting vertex. This would create a new edge, without "lighting up" a new vertex, and without creating a new region (because any point on the donut is still reachable from any other point on the donut, without crossing any edges).

I hypothesize you can only do this once though, because after you make this cut around the small radius of the torus, and because you aren't allowed to cross any edges again, you can unroll the torus into a tube, which makes it homeomorphically equivalent to a sphere, for which the formula still holds true.

Heres how I thought about it:

STEP 1: Assume there are only two houses (A & B) and two utilities (i & ii). Because each house must connect to the two utilities, and each utility must connect to the two houses, we can arrange them in an alternating sequence, with the last then connecting to the first. The circular nature of this sequence creates a bounded region.

A ___ 01 ____ B _____ 02
| |
|_____________________|


STEP 2: When we add the next letter (C) we ostensibly have two options: to put it inside or outside the region bounded in Step 1 (A1B2). If we choose to put it outside, we have another two options: to go directly to each number, or to wrap around point A

i.) C is placed outside and direct path. Two regions are C1B2 and A1B2

______________________
| |
A ___ 01 ____ B _____ 02 ___ C
| |
|_____________________|



ii.) C is placed outside and indirect path. Two regions are C1A2 and B1A2

_______________
| |
| A ___ 01 ____ B _____ 02 ____ C
| | | |
| |_____________________| |
|____________________________________|



iii.) C is placed inside. Two regions are A1C2 and B1C2

A ___ 01 ____ B _____ 02 ____
| | | |
| |______ C ______| |
|___________________________|


Notice that these are fundamentally the same outcome, just with the letters swapped around. There are always two regions created which share three vertices (both numbers and a letter) and thus they share an edge. (in i. the shared edge is 1B2, in ii. it is 1A2, and in iii. it is 1C2) Notice that the letters that are vertices for only one of the regions are always found outside the region they are not a vertex of. Because these are the same outcome, we can rename the letters in each to unify them into one diagram.


_______________________
| x |
A ___ 01 ____ B _____ 02 ___ C
| y |
|_____________________|


STEP 3: Because they share an edge, the two regions (now labeled x and y) can also be thought of as one large shape (A1C2, or x+y). There are three shared vertices (1, B, and 2) and because B is between points 1 and point 2, B will always lie somewhere on the shared edge, and thus will be enclosed within the singular large shape x+y. If we temporarily restrict our focus to only x+y, the space is separated into two sections, within the x+y and outside of it. If two points are connected, they must both be within the shape or both be outside. The final vertex to add is 3, which will have to connect to B. B is contained within x+y, so 3 must also be inside x+y. Therefore point 3 will be in region x or region y. If we temporarily restrict our focus to only x, the space is separated into two sections, within x and outside of it. A is outside of x. 3 must connect to A. Therefore 3 is outside of x. If we temporarily restrict our focus to only y, the space is separated into two sections, within y and outside of it. C is outside of y. 3 must connect to C. Therefore 3 is outside of y.

So the conclusions we have drawn are:
- Point 3 must be inside either region x or region y
- Point 3 must not be inside region x.
- Point 3 must not be inside region y

The most elegant way I can put the why it works:
When you run a line along the handle, both sides of the line are still the same region because they connect via the "inside" of the handle (you can get from one side to the other without crossing any edges, just going around the handle itself).
Since one of the edges is no longer creating a new region, you now need only 4 regions to solve the graph, and so it just became possible. :)

Another solution emerges when you don't treat the houses as zero dimensional uncrossable points, but rather areas you can draw through.  Connect a line from "Gas" to the top left corner of the left house, and then draw a line from there straight through the tops of the other two houses.  Draw another line from the "water" to the middle right of the right house, and then draw a straight line from there through the middles of the other two houses.  Then draw a line from the "electricity" to the bottom of the middle house, and from there draw lines to the bottoms of the other two houses.  This is slightly more complicated but still solveable in the same manner if you specify that you must have 9 edges, and becomes reliant on the torus topology of the mug as shown in the video if you also specify that you can't cross the houses.

I think I've solved the homework. The main thing to note about the graph on a torus is that there are only three regions, two inside ones and an outside one. How the graph accomplishes that essentially relies on the fact that you can draw two lines starting from the same point on the torus and not actually divide the torus into different regions, by having them follow the "axes" of the torus. So, the last two lines of the graph pull the same trick, and don't divide the last region into the three that would be required on a plane. Ultimately, where I think the proof in the video fails on a torus is by assuming that any new edge added necessarily either hits a new vertex or divides a new face, which clearly isn't universally true.

The first way I thought to solve this worked (luck, I guess), but it doesn't use the handle at all. It goes like this (houses left to right are A, B, and C):
Connect the heat to house A directly.
Connect the electricity to house B directly.
Connect the water to house C directly.

Connect the heat to house B with a short diagonal line.
Connect the electricity to house C with a short diagonal line.
Connect the water to house A by going to the right, across the side of the mug (alternatively, this line can just go up and around houses B and C, and later your water line to house B will go right under this line).

Connect the heat to house C by going left across the side of the mug (underneath the previous water line), then going underneath the water source and going up between the water and electricity sources.
Connect the electricity to house A by going down, underneath and around the entire mug vertically.
And finally just connect the water to house B by going around house C.

Too much detail lost in the 'ba-da-bing'. While I understand the direction your demonstration is going, I would have appreciated something more lucid. My perception of the steps in the demonstration are below. Each dot is a concept, distance between dots is amount of information required to reach it given the last:
.. .. ... "ba-da-bing" . "isn't that slick?"
This is not to say that I do not think your demonstration of this relation is consistent with mathematical rules, but without a clear conception of the behavior inherent to the problem that must give rise to the property you describe, any demonstration of the property you defined I have to take it on faith (which I don't, as a scientist), so I do not believe it. That is not to say I do not believe it is likely a proof, it seems like it may well be, but I have no idea what the behavior you are trying to describe is as the explanation of that seems lost in the rampage to a derivation of Euler's formalism on the subject. I do not believe the behavior because the intuition was not communicated (to me) so any formalisms on top of that are (to me) doodles.

For instance you could say that the Sun is the wheel of Apollo's chariot or that it is a massive ball of incandescent gas. So long as your explanation is consistent with measurable information and derivable fact, I have no opinion on what the Sun is. If we didn't have space travel, I would not have much trouble with either explanation of the nature of the Sun. I might believe one over the other, but so long as you do not claim that the length of a day or any of the other facts of its existence are different, it does not matter to me. So if your explanation is consistent with the data I have, if you do not contradict what is known, I can agree with it, even if I do not believe it.

This is the fundamental disconnect between science and mathematics, as I have seen. Science is very denotational - you describe what is and hypothesize possible behaviors or relations. Mathematics is very connotational - you project a behavior in to a formalism and deduce potential similarities of form. This is also the source of my frustration with mathematical texts. They seem never to be interested in having me agree with their projections and claims by supplying evidence. Given evidence, I can determine a model for the mechanism that gave rise to it, I am not in the business of taking a partial behavior or model and projecting all possible incarnations and outcomes.

Ironically, my approach was not to design a proof that a 6-vertex 9-edge graph was impossible in 2-D, but to create a 3D hexahedron (triangular bipyramid) to guide my intuition about the cup (another 3D object).

Imagine two tetrahedra sharing a face composed of the three cottages. Aloft is the gas utility and below is the power utility (axial positions). In the center of the 3-cottage triangle is the water utility. In this hexahedron, each cottage is serviced by all three utilities with no lines crossing in 3D.

Now imagine the grabbing the above described hexahedron by its equatorial "handle". Immediately one sees two key connection paths: one along the handle and one through the handle.

While I like the proof, I can't help but feel it misses the heart of the matter. If you add a tenth line to be drawn to the problem (like from the gas to the water dispenser), we can add the 5th region we needed and the proof would tell us there's nothing wrong. But obviously, if the ninth line already forces us to cross over, then a tenth line would just make things even worse.

In other words, the proof tells us that there aren't enough lines to go around, when in reality, there are too many. Can't help but feel left unsatisfied by that.

---------

Clearly, the proof uses the stipulation on the connections (i.e. all cycles are of length 4 or more), and without it, a planar graph with 6 vertices and 10 edges would work – like a pentagon with all neighbouring points connected, and then a sixth point in the center that connects to all the others. If you want a 6/9 graph, you can just remove one of those edges too.

So I don't know what the proof is missing, and what a more generalisable version would look like.

Some nice things about the last puzzle which generalise nicely. Label the coins by 1,2,3 and let X be the set of states of the coins, also let g be state with 3 gold sides. The set of all possible flips of X clearly form a group under composition. Id, (1 2) , (2 3) and (1 3) are elements of this group hence it is given by S3. S3 acts on X by flips. Since any flip preserves the "evenness" or "oddness" of the number of gold sides up of a configuration it follows that we have at least two orbits of this action. Any element in the set of all states with an odd number of gold sides differs by 2 or 0 gold sides from g. If they differ by 0 it's trivial and if they differ by 2 we can let S3 act on the element by exchanging the two places that differ so the orbit of the g is precisely the set of all states with an odd number of gold sides.

The line that goes through the handle doesn't create any new regions; the coffee mug handle acts as a bridge that connects two regions.

And that seems to be the essence of topology. When you take a plane, or a planar graph, or any traditional 2-dimensional euclidean entity that obeys normal laws of euclidean geometry, you can pick 2 or more points, or even 2 or more line segments, and arrogantly declare: "I declare these points/lines to be exactly the same!" When you "identify" those points or lines, you are pretty much saying that if a drawn line passes through one of those points or lines, they have the option of teleporting to the other points or lines.

For instance, with a rectangle, you can "identify" opposite edges, and declare them equivalent to each other: https://aminsaied.github.io/images/tda-top-2/quotient-torus.png. When you do that, you get a torus. It's essentially teleportation, and it results in some funky geometry.

Here's a good way to look at where the logic breaks down. Imagine drawing a square around one of the edges of the handle, so that one of the edges of the square goes through the handle. Closing the 4-point graph, you are at a point where you've moved from a lit point to another lit point. So, theoretically, you should have created another region, right? Except, if you flood-fill from inside the square, it skips over the handle to the outside, causing the entire mug to be filled. In other words, no new region was created. However, we can only do this trick once, as if we consider the square as "cutting" our mug, we're now left with something that is topologically similar to a cylinder, which, in turn, is topologically similar to a plane. So we basically get the "equivalent" of one region "for free", but no more than that.

The error comes from the number of regions. When you create a single loop on a sphere or plane, it separates the total region into two sections. However, there is still only one region is you do the same thing on a torus. Cut through a ball, you cut it into two pieces. If you cut through a donut from an outside point into the hole, it's still in one piece. This means you'll only need to make four regions at the end, so you only need eight edges and we have nine.

I think the introduction of a third dimension (by the mug handle) is where the proof breaks. It essentially adds depth along with height and width making it possible to "cross lines " as multiple lines can simply co-exist in layers or planes. If we remove the handle, the surface of the mug is essentially a cylindrically shaped sheet of paper where the lines by no means can cross each other. The edges available are still 8 though. The extra dimension just acts as a "bridge", if that makes sense.

As a mathematician at heart, seeing the physicists all struggle with this while the mathematicians like James Grime all had known it since they were little kids really warmed my heart.
This is a really common problem on a flat sheet where the solution is to poke two holes in the paper as draw the lines through them.

Doing the homework:





"Last line must introduce 5th region" and indeed it still does. But what doesn't hold anymore when we make the last connection over the handle is the previous assumption that "each edge touches exactly 2 regions". Introducing the "over handle" connection some lines will now touch 3 regions.

For the solved puzzle we have:
3 lines that touch 3 regions
5 lines that touch 2 regions
1 line that touches 1 region

My approach to proving the puzzle impossible, many years ago, was to rearrange the things to be connected.  Take two houses and two utilities, connect them to make a square.  Take the remaining utility and, place it inside the square and connect it up.  You now have 3 regions described by a cycle that contains only 2 of the 3 utilities, proving that nowhere you place the last house can connect to all 3.  Sure, it's not a neat formula but it's a nice easy way of demonstrating to non-math people.

my take on the homework:














if the graph is contained inside a simply connected region of space V-E+F=2 (because it would look the same on a plane)
if not, but it is contained within a strip (where a strip is homeomorphic to a region of a cylinder bounded by two circles) then V-E+F=1
if not, then V-E+F=2

this is because given 3 vertices A B C and assuming A is lit up and B, C aren't, joining A-B and B-C they're all lit up. then joining A-C will not light up new vertices, but it won't create a new region either. doing this for 2 perpendicular circles on a torus will prove it.

Ik, it's not entirely rigourous, but... eh, it works I guess.

Say we have 4 vertices, and we have 2 vertices with their edge going through the hole and 2 other vertices with their edge going around the hole, they won't intersect, and it works because they're going 2 different directions. This is basically a bridge, and since we are left with 2 houses and 2 utilities at the end of the puzzle we have 2+2=4 vertices in total, and with the hole these 4 total vertices will have no problem connecting at all! This means that the solution to the mug puzzle is perfectly reasonable as long as you consider this hole.

For those wondering what Looking Glass was doing: where previously they drew a sphere and tried to solve the problem on the sphere, they noticed that the mug was homeomorphic not to a sphere but to a torus (donut shape); they then did the same approach and drew a torus on the paper, then drew the connections on the torus.

Maybe I have some pro-topology bias, but I immediately assumed the handle must be necessary, even before I went through the time-consuming grunt work of finding a solution. I extremely pleased to see that nearly all channels contacted found the same solution I did. I know some of them have seen something like this before, but I'm sure not all of them did, and it is really a great lesson and demonstration of how a topological distinction matters. It's not just "some weird rule" mathematicians made to equate coffee mugs to donuts, it's a fundamental difference in connectivity with applications to plenty of real-world problems. In "baby math" like calculus, we paper over these important distinctions so we don't miss the techniques needed to calculate more general problems, but we do so at the expense of generality.

A fun extra puzzle: the video tells you that you can't solve the puzzle on a plane or on a sphere (also not on a cylinder or a on regular strip of paper with ends joined to form a ring), but that you can solve it on a torus. Can you solve it on a (mathematical) Möbius strip? ;)

P.S. By a mathematical Möbius strip I mean a mathematically thin one where points on both "sides" are actually considered to be the same points. For many properties of Möbius strips it doesn't matter if you make it out of paper and travel on the surface of the paper (a physical Möbius strip), or if you consider the mathematical version, which would correspond to traveling inside the paper; but for the posed puzzle it matters profoundly. Specifically, you have to circle the physical Möbius strip "twice" to return to the starting point, i.e. the curve on the surface has to sweep out 720 degrees in 3D space to return to the starting point (because after 360 degrees you end up on the other side of the paper from where you started), whereas the mathematical Möbius strip has to be circled only once to return to the starting point (i.e. after 360 degrees in 3D space you are back to where you started, and you didn't end up on the other side of the paper - you were inside the paper from the get go).

So, to attempt the puzzle: glue yourself a real physical Möbius strip out of paper, but allow yourself to tunnel through the thin sheet of paper to its opposite side at any point (or points) you wish to (this is equivalent to being on a mathematical Möbius strip). Happy puzzle solving! ;)

P.P.S. Extra extra: could you solve it on a physical Möbius strip without tunneling? Why/why not? :)

Draw a diamond. Two opposite corners are red. The other two are blue.

When you have two red and two blue, you must make this diamond to connect both reds to both blues.

Notice that the diamond is a closed space. The area inside is sealed. Now, to your drawing add a third blue point - inside or outside the diamond, the result is the same: you now have a diamond with a line through it, connecting two opposite red corners through a third blue point. You have two closed spaces sharing a side.

You cannot add a third red point, because it would need to be inside both of those closed spaces, on either side of the shared line.

*edited for clarity

The planar proof breaks down on the surface of a mug, aka a torus, because the torus isn't planar. It is comparable to a quadrilateral bounded plane, but whose pairs of opposite sides are connected, allowing lines to pass through one and essentially jump right to the other side of the plane without making a path to there.
This property allows two lines, one going through one side and the other going through the adjacent one, to cross each other without actually meeting.
Thus, a graph like K3,3 is possible to make without intersections on a torus, because its topology is essentially a plane with side-wrapping.

So I was then naturally thinking about proving the Euler Characteristic formula, V-E+F=2. The method I was thinking is by induction on E. Suppose that E=0, then in order for a graph to exist, V=1 and then F=1, the whole plane surrounding that vertex, hence the formula. When we have E=n, suppose that V=V(n) and F=F(n). Then when E=n+1, V(n+1)-V(n)=1 or F(n+1)-F(n)=1. Hence if we define S(n)=V(n)-E+F(n), then S(n+1)-S(n)=0. Therefore S should be constant for all n. But since we have proven that S(0)=2, hence the formula.

And I have thought about Eulars characteristic and found out, why it breaks down on a torus. We first need to think away of the vertices and only think of connected edges.
On a flat plane or a sphere, creating a connected edge means creating a new plane. On a torus, however, this isn't always the case. If you create a new edge without using the hole i.e. the edge neither go around nor through the hole, you get a new plane.
However, once you incoorperate the hole (e.g. going around or through the hole), this doesn't work properly. You only get a new plane if you already have an edge if you add another edge of the same kind.

That means, we have three kinds when you create a connected edge:
- It goes around the hole (edge A)
- It goes through the hole (edge B)
- Neither of the above (edge C)
This gets even more complicated since edge A and B don't really affect each other. This means, if the torus already has got an edge A. This means, if you don't use edge C then the amount of planes you get is A * B unless the result zero in which case it counts as one.

This anomaly allows you to solve the puzzle. One edge has to go around the hole (or in this case, use the cup's handle as a bridge), some others through the hole/ handle and the rest don't go near the hole/ handle.

A similar problem occurs on a 2D Torus, a circular plane with a hole in the center. If you make an edge which doesn't touch both, the outer and inner edge at the same time (i.e. edge A or C on a torus), you always get a new plane. However, if the edge question touches both already existing edges, all you have done is to add an edge without getting a new one (as long, as you don't touch an edge C or there already exist a such edge, that's it).

I think I figured out where the proof breaks down because I was thinking what the relationship was between the mug and the piece of paper (2D plane) is. The solution is that it is impossible to spread the mug out on to a 2D plane without the mug overlapping it's own plane at some point.

If we take the mug without the handle and flatten it out to be a 2D plane that is fairly easy to do. But when we add the handle, no matter how we try to slice the mug we can never create a scenario where the planes of the mug and the plane of the handle are not overlapping.

If we take the flattened mug as it's own entity, that is plane 1 and that occupies coordinates (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) on plane 1 which are the coordinates that the original mug and handle share when in their original structure. Now if we flatten out the handle and call that plane 2 and then we try to overlap the planes, no matter how we try to distort the 2D planes of plane 1 and plane 2, they always share coordinates (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) between their respective planes.

The shared coordinates between their planes allows for an external line to be drawn that is separate from both plane 1 and plane 2, therefore allowing a shortcut between plane 1 and plane 2 to be made allowing for the puzzle to be possible.

This is all because of the constraint that the plane of the mug and the plane of the handle have to be conjoined because 3D objects are conjoined in a perfect mathematical world where physics doesn't exist. This solution does not work if you want to apply quantum mechanics to incredibly small objects (protons, neutrons, quarks, etc. are never actually touching).

TL;DR You can't make a mug into a single 2D plane, so shortcuts.

Spoiler for the last challenge (why the proof breaks down on a torus):



If you start on the outer "equator" of a torus with one lit vertex and one region (the whole surface), you can run an edge a half way around the equator and light up a 2nd vertex. Then you can run a second edge the rest of the way around the torus back to the already-lit original vertex. This is where you'd pick a side of the edge you just drew and start painting in your region on a plane, but on a torus you'd find that by following the paint through the hole, you come straight to the other side of your edge. So both sides of the equator are the same color, and the same region, i.e., we have the same number of regions (1) that we started with. This means that, unlike a plane (@11:20), a torus allows you to add a new edge WITHOUT adding a vertex or creating a new region.

In particular, this means that we don't have to try to use our guaranteed 9 edges to try to make a whole 5 regions. In other words, the number of regions will be 4 at the most. So, by the same logic in the video, 4 regions with 4 edges each (@9:50) means 16 edges, and since this tally double-counts the edges (@10:35), we only need 8 edges (at the most), so we have 1 to spare! QED

The reason it breaks down for a torus is because of the whole, "Every new edge either creates a new vertex or a new region." If you picture the same game on a torus, and start connecting the dots the same way (top left, bottom left, top middle bottom middle) so now you have a sort of "lightning bolt" looking shape. On a piece of paper, you're forced to create a new region by connecting the middle bottom to the top left, by going a bit down, then to the left, than back up again, finally connecting back up to the top left. But on a torus, you can take the path downwards, around the doughnut, circling back to the top, and connecting to the top left node. This splits the initial region, but it does not create a new region. If you take a doughnut, and take a bite out of it, it's still in one piece. So you just created a new edge without creating a new vertex, and without creating a new region. There's the problem.

The proof breaks down on a torus at the part where you show that an edge can only add at most exactly 1 new region. On a torus (or other equivalent surface), an edge could potentially add more than one region. Consider a graph, on the surface of a torus (donut), with a single vertex. Now draw an edge that starts at the vertex and loops around the donut the long way back to the same vertex. You've split the space into two regions from one; that added 1 region, like we've been doing.

But now add another edge, again from the only vertex back into itself... only this time, go around the smaller circumference of the torus. You can do that without crossing the other edge. By doing this, you've split the surface into 4 regions... but before we had 2! So you've actually added 2 regions with one edge, whereas the proof on a plane depended on being able to only add a single region per edge.

Before watching the solution, here's my guess:
So this is a basic problem with regards to planar graphs. A graph can only be planar (i.e. no ligns crossing), when it doesn't contain the graphs K5 (5 nodes, connections between each) or K3,3 (exactly what this video is about). Proof by Kuratowski, if anyone's interested (it's a really long proof). So if it's possble on the mug it has to do with topology, which means that the handle is the key. One line has to go through, on around the handle. That's my guess.

10:47 On a plane extending the outside edges will never cause edges to meet, and 5 regions will require 10 edges. However, on a torus, the top edge can be extended until it meets the bottom edge, and the left can be extended to meet the right edge, resulting in only 8 edges needed to draw 5 regions. I believe this is where proving the task impossible breaks down for the case of the mug.

the place where the logic breaks down for the torus is in assuming that drawing an edge has to either lit a vertex or enclose a region. On torus the latter is not true - it is possible to draw two edges that connect the same two vertices but do not cut out a flat face, but instead cut the torus into a cylinder. Also, this only works exactly once, because once the torus is cut into cylinder you are in normal flat territory again.

The flaw in the reasoning is that every closed region is bound by exactly 4 edges. I've done it a few times at this point, and  experimentally, either closed regions are bound by 6 edges, or there are 2 regions bound by 4 edges and one region that is bound by 6 edges but also contains  2 edges- i.e. has 2 edges that bound the same region on both sides (i.e. violates jordan curve theorem). I really dont like this, because it implies that for the K3,3 bipartite graph, how you draw it changes which regions there are. At least there are the same number of regions, but I'm not sure if thats better. 

 Note that on a torus, say that you draw the line connecting 4 vertices. This is only 1 region, because you can go "around" the torus in the other direction.

But, this implies that the true error after connecting to a "lit" vertex, a new region is formed, since thats false at least once. 

Im not quite yet happy with this, but its as close as I can get. 

When I thought that it had to be 3 regions each bound by 6 edges, I thought I was getting close to showing each region had to touch each vertex. But, then I found the example where thats not the case, and the third region "contains" 2 edges. That suddenly got messy because then I had to show that it is 3 regions instead.

You "almost" get there, by showing that the minimum number of lines that can be drawn on the graph such that each edge is part of exactly one line and the lines are connected is 3, because there are 6 vertices of degree 3. This is almost good enough, because the idea is that if a line also acts a boundary for the region, then it would have to start or end there. But then that would imply up to 6 regions, not 3.

Explanation of where the proof breaks down:

I think the proofs hold in general if you replace the word 'regions' with 'loops'. The problem with the proof is that it assumes that a closed loop creates separate inside and outside regions, which is only true if you're on a surface without any holes. If you do have a hole like on the mug, a loop going around the hole or a loop going through the hole will not give you a new enclosed region, because the 'inside' and 'outside' of the loop are still connected to each other. Therefore, by crossing two lines using the handle of the mug you reduce the number of regions from 5 to 3 and the puzzle is solvable.

The reason you're proof doesn't work on a torus is because the regions are not enclosed when a line goes around the torus. It extends around the surface of the torus to the other side of the line. Therefore, 4 lines on a torus do not always enclose a region.

It breaks down because you can connect a light up point with itself on a torus without separating the torus into two different regions. You can easily just transform this specific line into a single point by squeezing the sides together. Or you could transform it into two unconnected points on a topological sphere by severing the connection point. If you tried to do the same with a sphere you would just double the sphere leaving one point on each.
